title: Azure Kubernetes Service Container Escape via Privileged Pod

timeline.event: Container escape vulnerability discovered in AKS node configuration
Microsoft confirms vulnerability and begins developing patch
Microsoft releases security update for AKS
CISA adds to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog after active exploitation detected

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical container escape vulnerability was found in Azure Kubernetes Service. If an attacker can run code inside a container, they can break out and take control of the underlying node. From there, they can access other containers and potentially the entire cluster.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations running workloads on Azure Kubernetes Service, especially those allowing untrusted container images or multi-tenant Kubernetes clusters. AKS clusters without Pod Security Standards are most vulnerable.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker gains access to a container (via app vulnerability or malicious image). Step 2: They exploit a kernel vulnerability to escape the container. Step 3: They gain root access on the AKS node. Step 4: They access secrets, service account tokens, and other containers. Step 5: They can pivot to other nodes and take over the cluster.
what_you_should_do: Update AKS clusters to the latest patched version immediately
Enable Azure Policy for Kubernetes to enforce pod security standards
Disable privileged containers unless absolutely necessary
Implement network policies to limit pod-to-pod communication
Review all running pods for elevated privileges
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Container escapes are among the most dangerous cloud vulnerabilities. Once an attacker escapes a container, they have direct access to the host and potentially all other workloads. In shared Kubernetes clusters, this means one compromised application can lead to a complete infrastructure breach.

tactics.description: Attackers escape container isolation to access the underlying host
Attackers steal service account tokens to move between pods
Attackers access Kubernetes API to extract secrets

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for suspicious container activity, privilege escalation attempts, and unusual process execution on AKS nodes. Enable Azure Defender alerts.

log_sources.description: Container-level logs and metrics for AKS clusters
Runtime threat detection for container workloads
API server audit logs for cluster activity

what_to_look_for.description: Pods created with privileged: true or hostPID/hostNetwork enabled
Containers mounting host paths like /etc, /var, or /proc
Unexpected processes running in containers (nsenter, chroot)

immediate_actions.description: Upgrade to the latest AKS version with security patches
Apply restricted pod security standards to namespaces
Find all pods running with elevated privileges
Turn on runtime protection for AKS workloads
immediate_actions.command: az security pricing create --name Containers --tier Standard
